Aunque su origen es incierto, muchos historiadores creen que los escequelios son una rama de los antiguos sármatas, un pueblo nómada que habitaba en la región antes de la llegada de los hunos. La cultura escequelia es única y fascinante, con una mezcla de influencias bárbaras y cristianas. Sus tradiciones se han mantenido viva a lo largo de los siglos, y su lengua y costumbres siguen siendo una fuente de interés para los historiadores y antropólogos. A pesar de su aislamiento, los escequelios han tenido un impacto significativo en la historia de Transilvania, y su legado continúa siendo una parte importante de la identidad regional. En la actualidad, los escequelios siguen viviendo en sus montañas natales, manteniendo viva su cultura y tradiciones, y compartiendo su historia con el mundo. Su conexión con Atila y los hunos es un tema de debate entre los historiadores, pero lo que es cierto es que los escequelios han dejado una huella indeleble en la historia de Transilvania.

Su mirada me hizo sentir incómodo, pero también me dio la sensación de que estaba a punto de descubrir algo importante. "¿Qué crees que podría estar pasando en este lugar?", agregó, como si estuviera tratando de sacar algo de mí. Su voz era baja y persuasiva, y me sentí tentado a decirle algo, pero no sabía qué. en_first_half: I had hardly come to this conclusion when I heard the great door below shut, and knew that the Count had returned. He did not come at once into the library, so I went cautiously to my own room and found him making the bed. This was odd, but only confirmed what I had all along thought—that there were no servants in the house. When later I saw him through the chink of the hinges of the door laying the table in the dining-room, I was assured of it; for if he does himself all these menial offices, surely it is proof that there is no one else to do them. This gave me a fright, for if there is no one else in the castle, it must have been the Count himself who was the driver of the coach that brought me here. This is a terrible thought; for if so, what does it mean that he could control the wolves, as he did, by only holding up his hand in silence. How was it that all the
en_second_half: people at Bistritz and on the coach had some terrible fear for me? What meant the giving of the crucifix, of the garlic, of the wild rose, of the mountain ash? Bless that good, good woman who hung the crucifix round my neck! for it is a comfort and a strength to me whenever I touch it. It is odd that a thing which I have been taught to regard with disfavour and as idolatrous should in a time of loneliness and trouble be of help. Is it that there is something in the essence of the thing itself, or that it is a medium, a tangible help, in conveying memories of sympathy and comfort? Some time, if it may be, I must examine this matter and try to make up my mind about it. In the meantime I must find out all I can about Count Dracula, as it may help me to understand. To-night he may talk of himself, if I turn the conversation that way. I must be very careful, however, not to awake his suspicion.

es_results_raw: Me levanté de la cama y me dirigí hacia la habitación de Renfield, sintiendo un sentimiento de preocupación por mi paciente. Al llegar, encontré a mi asistente, el señor Utterson, sentado en una silla, con una expresión seria en su rostro. "¿Qué ha pasado?", le pregunté, mientras me acercaba a la cama de Renfield. El señor Utterson me informó que Renfield había estado hablando de manera incoherente durante la noche, y que había comenzado a comer plumas de las aves del jardín. Me pareció que la situación estaba empeorando rápidamente y decidí llamar al doctor Seward para que viniera a evaluar a mi paciente. Mientras esperaba a que llegara el doctor, me senté en la silla que había ocupado el señor Utterson y comencé a observar a Renfield, que yacía en la cama, con una mirada vacía en los ojos. Su respiración era irregular y su cuerpo temblaba ligeramente. De repente, Renfield abrió los ojos y me miró con una expresión de terror en su rostro. "¿Qué es lo que te pasa, Renfield?", le pregunté, tratando de mantener la calma. Renfield comenzó a hablar de manera incoherente, diciendo algo sobre un "gran gato" que lo perseguía y lo estaba matando. Me pareció que estaba perdiendo la cordura y decidí llamar al doctor Seward de inmediato para que viniera a ayudarme a tratar a mi paciente.

He said that in his watch he had been sheltering behind the deck-house, as there was a rain-storm, when he saw a tall, thin man, who was not like any
en_second_half: of the crew, come up the companion-way, and go along the deck forward, and disappear. He followed cautiously, but when he got to bows found no one, and the hatchways were all closed. He was in a panic of superstitious fear, and I am afraid the panic may spread. To allay it, I shall to-day search entire ship carefully from stem to stern.

Olgaren described the man as having a pale face and sunken eyes, with a black coat that was drenched from the rain. He said that the man was standing at the ship's rail, staring out at the sea with an intensity that made him shiver. At first, Olgaren thought it was just his imagination, but as he watched, the man began to move towards the bow of the ship, his long strides eating up the distance. Olgaren was so startled that he nearly fell overboard in his haste to get out of the way. He didn't see the man again after that, but he couldn't shake the feeling that he had seen something truly unusual. I asked him if he was sure it wasn't just a hallucination brought on by the storm, but he swore it was real. I've been thinking about it all day, and I have to admit, I'm starting to wonder if there's any truth to his story. Could it be that we're not alone on this ship after all? I've been trying to keep an eye out for any sign of the mysterious stranger, but so far, I haven't seen anything. The crew is starting to get restless, and I'm not sure how much longer I can keep this from them. I've decided to do some investigating of my own, to see if I can uncover any clues about the strange man. I've been talking to the other crew members, trying to see if anyone else has seen anything, but so far, no one seems to have noticed anything out of the ordinary. I've also been checking the ship's manifest, but it doesn't seem to list anyone who matches Olgaren's description. I'm starting to feel like I'm going crazy, but I know I have to keep looking. I've decided to check the cargo hold, to see if there's anything that might explain what Olgaren saw. It's a long shot, but I have to try. As I make my way down to the hold, I can feel a sense of unease growing inside me. What if I do find something? What if it's something I don't want to know? I push the thoughts aside and focus on the task at hand. The cargo hold is dimly lit, the only sound the creaking of the ship and the distant rumble of thunder. I fumble for my lantern and light it, casting flickering shadows on the walls. The air is musty and filled with the smell of damp wood and salt. I begin to make my way through the crates and boxes, searching for anything out of the ordinary. As I move deeper into the hold, I start to feel a sense of disorientation. The crates seem to be shifting and rearranging themselves, and I have to navigate through a maze of narrow aisles. I'm starting to feel a sense of unease, like I'm being watched. I quicken my pace, my heart pounding in my chest. Suddenly, I hear a faint noise behind me. I spin around, but there's no one there. I'm about to turn back to my search when I see a small, unmarked crate in the corner of the hold. It's partially hidden by a stack of crates, and it looks out of place among the rest. I approach it cautiously, my senses on high alert. As I reach out to touch it, I feel a sudden jolt of electricity run through my body. I pull my hand back, my heart racing. What is this crate, and why does it feel so... alive? I take a deep breath and try to calm myself down. I'm just being paranoid, I tell myself. I'm just being spooked by the storm and Olgaren's story. But as I look at the crate, I know I'm not convinced. I'm going to open it, no matter what. I take a deep breath and lift the lid, and what I see inside makes my blood run cold. It's a small, leather-bound book, adorned with strange symbols and markings. I feel a shiver run down my spine as I pick it up, feeling an inexplicable connection to it. As I open the book, I see that the pages are filled with handwritten notes, written in a language I don't understand. But as I touch the pages, I feel a sudden surge of knowledge flood through my mind. I know what this book is, and what it contains. It's a journal, written by the mysterious stranger who Olgaren saw on the ship. And it's not just any journal - it's a journal of dark and forbidden knowledge. I feel a sense of horror wash over me as I realize the implications of what I've found. We're not alone on this ship,

en_first_half: When I bent over her I could see that she was still asleep. Her lips were parted, and she was breathing—not softly as usual with her, but in long, heavy gasps, as though striving to get her lungs full at every breath. As I came close, she put up her hand in her sleep and pulled the collar of her nightdress close around her throat. Whilst she did so there came a little shudder through her, as though she felt the cold. I flung the warm shawl over her, and drew the edges tight round her neck, for I dreaded lest she should get some deadly chill from the night air, unclad as she was. I feared to wake her all at once, so, in order to have my hands free that I might help her, I fastened the shawl at her throat with a big safety-pin; but I must have been clumsy in my anxiety and pinched or pricked her with it, for by-and-by, when her breathing became quieter, she put her hand to her throat again and moaned. When I had her carefully wrapped up I put my shoes on her feet and then began very gently to wake her. At first she did not respond; but gradually she became more and
en_second_half: more uneasy in her sleep, moaning and sighing occasionally. At last, as time was passing fast, and, for many other reasons, I wished to get her home at once, I shook her more forcibly, till finally she opened her eyes and awoke. She did not seem surprised to see me, as, of course, she did not realise all at once where she was. Lucy always wakes prettily, and even at such a time, when her body must have been chilled with cold, and her mind somewhat appalled at waking unclad in a churchyard at night, she did not lose her grace. She trembled a little, and clung to me; when I told her to come at once with me home she rose without a word, with the obedience of a child. As we passed along, the gravel hurt my feet, and Lucy noticed me wince. She stopped and wanted to insist upon my taking my shoes; but I would not. However, when we got to the pathway outside the churchyard, where there was a puddle of water, remaining from the storm, I daubed my feet with mud, using each foot in turn on the other, so that as we went home, no one, in case we should meet any one, should notice my bare feet.

es_first_half: Cuando me incliné sobre ella pude ver que todavía dormía. Sus labios estaban abiertos, y ella estaba respirando, pero no con la suavidad acostumbrada sino a grandes y pesadas boqueadas, como si tratara de llenar plenamente sus pulmones a cada respiro. Al acercarme, subió la mano y tiró del cuello de su camisón de dormir, como si sintiera frío. Sin embargo, siguió dormida. Yo puse el caliente chal sobre sus hombros, amarrándole fuertemente las puntas alrededor del cuello, pues temía mucho que fuese a tomar un mortal resfrío del aire de la noche, así casi desnuda como estaba. Temí despertarla de golpe, por lo que, para poder tener mis manos libres para ayudarla, le sujeté el chal cerca de la garganta con un imperdible de gran tamaño; pero en mi ansiedad debo haber obrado torpemente y la pinché con él, porque al poco rato, cuando su respiración se hizo más regular, se llevó otra vez la mano a la garganta y gimió. Una vez que la hube envuelto cuidadosamente, puse mis zapatos en sus pies y comencé a despertarla con mucha suavidad. En un principio no respondía: pero gradualmente se volvió más y más inquieta en su sueño, gimiendo y suspirando ocasionalmente. Por fin, ya
es_second_half: que el tiempo pasaba rápidamente y, por muchas otras razones, yo deseaba llevarla a casa de inmediato, la zarandeé con más fuerza, hasta que finalmente abrió los ojos y despertó. No pareció sorprendida de verme, ya que, por supuesto, no se dio cuenta de inmediato de en dónde nos encontrábamos. Lucy se despierta siempre con bella expresión, e incluso en aquellos momentos, en que su cuerpo debía estar traspasado por el frío y su mente espantada al saber que había caminado semidesnuda por el cementerio en la noche, no pareció perder su gracia. Tembló un poco y me abrazó fuertemente; cuando le dije que viniera de inmediato conmigo de regreso a casa, se levantó sin decir palabra y me obedeció como una niña. Al comenzar a caminar, la grava me lastimó los pies, y Lucy notó mi salto. Se detuvo y quería insistir en que me pusiera mis zapatos, pero yo me negué. Sin embargo, cuando salimos al sendero afuera del cementerio, donde había un charco de agua, remanente de la tormenta, me unté los pies con lodo usando cada vez un pie sobre el otro, para que al ir a casa, nadie, en caso de que encontráramos a alguien, pudiera notar mis pies descalzos.

tr_first_half: Üzerine eğildiğimde hâlâ uyuduğunu görebiliyordum. Dudakları aralıktı ve nefes alıyordu - her zamanki gibi yumuşak değil, sanki her nefes alışında ciğerlerini tümüyle doldurmak istercesine uzun, derin nefeslerdi bunlar. Yanına yaklaştığım zaman, uykusunda elini kaldırdı ve geceliğinin yakasını boğazına sardı. Bunu yaparken, sanki soğuğu hissetmişçesine hafifçe ürperdi. Sıcak şalı üzerine attım ve kenarlarını boynunda iyice birleştirdim çünkü böylesine çıplakken gece havasında kötü biçimde üşütmesinden çekiniyordum. Onu birdenbire uyandırmaktan korktum, bu yüzden ellerimi boşaltıp ona yardım edebileyim diye şalı büyük bir çengelli iğneyle boğazında tutturdum; ama kaygıdan beceriksizce davranıp iğneyi boğazına batırmış ya da saplamış olmalıyım çünkü çok geçmeden, nefes alışı sakinleştiğinde elini bir kez daha boğazına götürüp inledi. Onu dikkatlice sarıp sarmaladığımda ayakkabılarımı ayaklarına geçirdim ve sonra onu yavaşça uyandırmaya başladım. Önce tepki vermedi, ama uykusunda ara sıra inleyerek ve iç çekerek giderek daha huzursuzlaştı. Zaman hızla
tr_second_half: akıp geçtiği için ve başka pek çok nedenden ötürü onu bir an önce eve götürmek istiyordum; sonunda gözlerini açıp uyanana kadar onu büyük güçle sarstım. Elbette, hemen nerede olduğunu anlamadığı için beni gördüğüne şaşırmış gibi görünmüyordu. Lucy hep çok güzel uyanır ve böyle bir zamanda, bedeni soğuktan üşümüşken, zihni gece vakti kilise bahçesinde üzerinde giysileri olmadan uyanmış olmasının etkisiyle biraz dehşete kapılmışken bile zarafetini yitirmedi. Biraz titredi ve bana sarıldı; hemen benimle eve gelmesini söylediğimde söz dinleyen çocuk gibi tek söz söylemeden ayağa kalktı. Yürürken, çakıltaşları ayaklarımı acıttı ve Lucy acıyla yüzümü buruşturduğumu fark etti. Durdu ve ayakkabılarımı almam için ısrar etmek istedi, ama kabul etmedim. en_first_half: “All right, guv’nor. This ’ere is about the ’ole story. That ’ere wolf what we called Bersicker was one of three grey ones that came from Norway to Jamrach’s, which we bought off him four years ago. He was
en_second_half: a nice well-behaved wolf, that never gave no trouble to talk of. I’m more surprised at ’im for wantin’ to get out nor any other animile in the place. But, there, you can’t trust wolves no more nor women.”
en_results: a big, scrawny thing, with a coat as black as coal and eyes that glowed like lanterns in the dark. We thought he was a bit of a scamp, always getting into trouble and causing a ruckus, but he was also fiercely
en_results_raw: ...a big, scrawny thing, with a coat as black as coal and eyes that glowed like lanterns in the dark. We thought he was a bit of a scamp, always getting into trouble and causing a ruckus, but he was also fiercely loyal to the pack. The other two, we called them Fang and Scorch, were a bit more docile, but Bersicker was the one who always seemed to be getting into the most mischief. He'd dig up the garden, chase the cats, and even try to steal food from the kitchen counter. But despite all the chaos he caused, we loved him dearly, and he was a beloved member of the family. As the years went by, Bersicker grew bigger and stronger, and his antics became more and more brazen. He'd jump up onto the furniture, knock over vases, and even try to "help" with the cooking. But deep down, we knew he was just a big softie, and we couldn't imagine life without him. Little did we know, however, that Bersicker's most infamous escapade was yet to come...

en_first_half: 17 September.—I was engaged after dinner in my study posting up my books, which, through press of other work and the many visits to Lucy, had fallen sadly into arrear. Suddenly the door was burst open, and in rushed my patient, with his face distorted with passion. I was thunderstruck, for such a thing as a patient getting of his own accord into the Superintendent’s study is almost unknown. Without an instant’s pause he made straight at me. He had a dinner-knife in his hand, and, as I saw he was dangerous, I tried to keep the table between us. He was too quick and too strong for me, however; for before I could get my balance he had struck at me and cut my left wrist rather severely. Before he
en_second_half: could strike again, however, I got in my right and he was sprawling on his back on the floor. My wrist bled freely, and quite a little pool trickled on to the carpet. I saw that my friend was not intent on further effort, and occupied myself binding up my wrist, keeping a wary eye on the prostrate figure all the time. When the attendants rushed in, and we turned our attention to him, his employment positively sickened me. He was lying on his belly on the floor licking up, like a dog, the blood which had fallen from my wounded wrist. He was easily secured, and, to my surprise, went with the attendants quite placidly, simply repeating over and over again: “The blood is the life! The blood is the life!”

en_results_raw: <output>The wound was deep and painful, and I felt a sense of shock wash over me as I gazed down at the blood dripping from my wrist. My patient, still wild-eyed and frenzied, continued to advance on me, the dinner-knife glinting menacingly in his hand. I tried to reason with him, to calm him down, but he seemed beyond reason. His eyes were fixed on me with a malevolent intensity, and I knew I had to act quickly to protect myself. I slowly backed away from the table, trying not to make any sudden movements that might provoke him further. As I retreated, I knocked over a chair, which fell to the floor with a loud crash, momentarily distracting my patient. In that brief moment of distraction, I managed to grab a nearby bookend and hold it up as a makeshift shield between us. The patient lunged at me again, but I was ready for him this time. I held my ground, the bookend at the ready, and tried to talk him down, to appeal to whatever rationality was left in him. But he was beyond listening, and I knew I had to think of something else, and fast, if I was going to get out of this situation alive. I glanced around the room, my eyes scanning the space for anything that could be used as a weapon or a means of escape. That's when I spotted it - the door to the study was slightly ajar, and I knew that if I could just manage to get to it, I might be able to make a run for it. But my patient was closing in, his eyes fixed on me with an unnerving intensity, and I knew I had to act fast if I was going to make it out of there alive. I took a deep breath, steeled myself, and made a break for the door, the bookend held tightly in front of me like a shield. My patient gave chase, his footsteps pounding the floor behind me as I sprinted towards the door. I could hear him shouting, his voice rising to a crescendo of rage and frustration, but I didn't dare look back. I kept my eyes fixed on the door, my heart pounding in my chest, and my mind racing with fear. I burst through the doorway and slammed it shut behind me, leaning against it to catch my breath and try to process what had just happened. I was shaken, but I knew I had to think clearly if I was going to get through this. I took a few deep breaths, trying to calm myself down, and then I began to think about what I needed to do next. I had to get help, and fast. I had to get my patient restrained and get him the help he so desperately needed. And I had to figure out what had triggered this violent outburst in the first place. I knew it wouldn't be easy, but I was determined to get to the bottom of it, no matter what it took. I slowly made my way to the nurse's station, my heart still racing from the adrenaline of the encounter. I knew I had to report what had happened, and I knew I had to do it quickly. I pushed open the door to the nurse's station, and was greeted by the concerned faces of the nurses on duty. "What happened?" one of them asked, her voice low and urgent. I took a deep breath, trying to compose myself, and began to explain. "He attacked me," I said, my voice shaking slightly. "He had a knife, and he cut me." The nurses gasped in shock, and one of them quickly called for the doctor. I knew I was in good hands now, and I felt a sense of relief wash over me. But I also knew that this was far from over. I had to get to the bottom of what had happened, and I had to make sure that my patient got the help he so desperately needed. I was determined to do whatever it took to make that happen, no matter what the cost. As I sat in the nurse's station, waiting for the doctor to arrive, I couldn't help but think about the events that had led up to this moment. I had been a doctor for many years, and I had seen my fair share of violent outbursts from patients. But this was different. This was personal. This was a patient who had been under my care, and I felt a sense of responsibility for what had happened. I knew I had to do everything in my power to make sure it never happened again. The doctor arrived, and I explained the situation to him. He listened intently, his face grave with concern. "We need to get him restrained," he said, his voice firm but calm. "And we need to figure out what triggered this outburst." I nodded in agreement, feeling a sense of determination wash over me
vi_first_half: • Ngày 17 tháng 9 Ăn tối xong, tôi quay về phòng, định bụng sẽ lên lịch cho những ngày làm việc tiếp theo. Bất thình lình, cánh cửa phòng tôi bỗng bật mở, tiếp đó là sự xuất hiện đường đột của Renfield: hắn lao thẳng về phía tôi với bộ mặt thật hung tợn. Tôi sững sờ đứng nhìn, bởi một bệnh nhân bất ngờ đến tìm bác sĩ trưởng mà không xin phép ai là một việc làm rất ít khi xảy ra ở đây. Tay hắn lăm lăm một con dao sáng loáng. Tôi ý thức ngay được rằng trong cơn điên, hắn có thể trở nên rất nguy hiểm, bởi vậy tôi phải cảnh giác lùi lại, định bụng sẽ lấy cái bàn gỗ làm chướng ngại vật ngăn cách hắn với tôi. Nhưng hắn đã nhanh hơn tôi, trước khi tôi kịp lấy lại thăng bằng, hắn đã vung tay chém tôi một nhát khá sâu vào cổ tay trái.
vi_second_half: Tuy nhiên, không để hắn vung dao lên lần thứ hai, tôi lập tức lao vào đẩy hắn ngã ngửa xuống sàn nhà. Máu từ vết thương ở tay tôi chảy túa ra thành một vũng nhỏ trên tấm thảm. Renfield vẫn nằm im, dường như không định tấn công lần nữa. Tới lúc đó tôi mới có thời gian băng bó vết thương trong khi mắt vẫn không rời khỏi gã bệnh nhân. Khi mấy tay giám thị tới, chúng tôi mới xúm lại xốc hắn dậy và đẩy hắn trở về phòng, song hắn đã giãy nảy lên và quay ngoắt lại để làm một việc khiến tôi một lần nữa phải kinh ngạc: hắn bò sát xuống sàn nhà giống như điệu bộ của một con chó, và lè lưỡi liếm sạch các vết máu vừa chảy xuống từ vết thương của tôi. Hắn vừa liếm láp vừa luôn mồm lải nhải mãi một câu: “Máu là cuộc sống? Máu là cuộc sống!”

Estaba ocupado, después de cenar, en mi estudio fechando mis libros, los cuales, debido a la urgencia de otros trabajos y a las muchas visitas a Lucy, se encontraban tristemente atrasados. De pronto, la puerta se abrió de golpe y mi paciente entró como un torbellino, con el rostro deformado por la ansiedad. Yo me sobresalté, pues es una cosa casi desconocida que un paciente entre de esa manera y por su propia cuenta en el despacho del superintendente. Sin hacer ninguna pausa se dirigió directamente hacia mí. En su mano había un cuchillo de cocina, y como vi que era peligroso, traté de mantener la mesa entre nosotros. Sin embargo, fue demasiado rápido y demasiado fuerte para mí; antes de que yo pudiera alcanzar mi equilibrio me había lanzado el primer golpe, cortándome bastante
es_second_half: profundamente la muñeca izquierda. Pero antes de que pudiera lanzarme otro golpe, le di un derechazo y cayó con los brazos y piernas extendidos por el suelo. Mi muñeca sangraba profusamente, y un pequeño charco se formó sobre la alfombra. Vi que mi amigo no parecía intentar otro esfuerzo, por lo que me ocupé en vendar mi muñeca, manteniendo todo el tiempo una cautelosa vigilancia sobre la figura postrada. Cuando mis asistentes entraron corriendo y pusimos nuestra atención sobre él, su aspecto positivamente me enfermó. Estaba acostado sobre el vientre en el suelo, lamiendo como un perro la sangre que había caído de mi muñeca herida. Lo sujetamos con facilidad, y, para sorpresa mía, se dejó llevar con bastante docilidad por los asistentes, repitiendo una y otra vez: –¡La sangre es la vida! ¡La sangre es la vida!

es_results_raw: <output>17 de septiembre. Estaba ocupado, después de cenar, en mi estudio fechando mis libros, los cuales, debido a la urgencia de otros trabajos y a las muchas visitas a Lucy, se encontraban tristemente atrasados. De pronto, la puerta se abrió de golpe y mi paciente entró como un torbellino, con el rostro deformado por la ansiedad. Yo me sobresalté, pues es una cosa casi desconocida que un paciente entre de esa manera y por su propia cuenta en el despacho del superintendente. Sin hacer ninguna pausa se dirigió directamente hacia mí. En su mano había un cuchillo de cocina, y como vi que era peligroso, traté de mantener la mesa entre nosotros. Sin embargo, fue demasiado rápido y demasiado fuerte para mí; antes de que yo pudiera alcanzar mi equilibrio me había lanzado el primer golpe, cortándome bastante. Me sentí un dolor agudo en la mano y me apreté el puño para detener la hemorragia. Mi paciente, sin dejar de mirarme con una expresión de locura en los ojos, se acercó más y más, el cuchillo en alto, listo para lanzar otro golpe. Me di cuenta de que debía actuar rápido, antes de que fuera demasiado tarde. Traté de hablar con él, de calmarlo, pero no parecía escucharme. Su rostro estaba tan contorsionado por la ira y la desesperación que parecía que no había nada que pudiera detenerlo. Me di cuenta de que debía defenderme, así que me preparé para recibir el próximo golpe. Pero justo cuando estaba a punto de lanzarse sobre mí, la puerta se abrió de nuevo y entró Lucy, con una expresión de preocupación en su rostro. Mi paciente se detuvo en seco, como si hubiera sido sorprendido en algo. Lucy se acercó a mí y me ayudó a levantarme, mientras que mi paciente se quedaba allí, con el cuchillo aún en la mano, mirándonos con una expresión de confusión. Me di cuenta de que Lucy había llegado justo a tiempo, y que mi vida había estado en peligro. Me sentí agradecido hacia ella, y me pregunté qué había pasado para que mi paciente se hubiera vuelto tan violento. ¿Qué había desencadenado esta crisis? ¿Qué había sucedido en su vida para que se sintiera tan desesperado? Me di cuenta de que debía saberlo, y que debía encontrar una forma de ayudarlo a superar esto. Me volví hacia Lucy y le pregunté qué había pasado, pero ella se limitó a sacudir la cabeza y decir que no lo sabía. Me di cuenta de que debía investigar más a fondo, y que debía encontrar la respuesta a esta pregunta. Así que comencé a preguntarle a mi paciente, pero él se negó a hablar, y se limitó a mirarme con una expresión de miedo en los ojos. Me di cuenta de que debía ser paciente, y que debía encontrar una forma de ganar su confianza. Así que me senté con él, y le hablé en un tono calmado y suave, tratando de hacerlo sentir cómodo. en_first_half: The time did not seem long, but very, very awful, till I recovered consciousness again. Somewhere near, a passing bell was tolling; the dogs all round the neighbourhood were howling; and in our shrubbery, seemingly just outside, a nightingale was singing. I was dazed and stupid with pain and terror and weakness, but the sound of the nightingale seemed like the voice of my dead mother come back to comfort me. The sounds seemed to have awakened the maids, too, for I could hear their bare feet pattering outside my door. I called to them, and they came in, and when they saw what had happened, and what it was that lay over me on the bed, they screamed out. The wind rushed in through the broken window, and the door slammed to. They lifted off the body
en_second_half: of my dear mother, and laid her, covered up with a sheet, on the bed after I had got up. They were all so frightened and nervous that I directed them to go to the dining-room and have each a glass of wine. The door flew open for an instant and closed again. The maids shrieked, and then went in a body to the dining-room; and I laid what flowers I had on my dear mother’s breast. When they were there I remembered what Dr. Van Helsing had told me, but I didn’t like to remove them, and, besides, I would have some of the servants to sit up with me now. I was surprised that the maids did not come back. I called them, but got no answer, so I went to the dining-room to look for them.

es_first_half: No pareció transcurrir mucho rato, sino más bien que fue muy, muy terrible, hasta que pude recobrar nuevamente la conciencia. Yo estaba aturdida y embotada de dolor, terror y debilidad, pero el sonido del ruiseñor pareció la voz de mi madre muerta que regresaba para consolarme. Los ruidos parece que también despertaron a las sirvientas, pues pude oír sus pisadas descalzas corriendo fuera de mi puerta. Las sirvientas gritaron horrorizadas, y luego se fueron en grupo compacto al comedor, y yo puse las flores que había tenido alrededor de mi cuello sobre el pecho de mi querida madre. He leaned forward, his voice low and measured, "Tell me, my dear child, how do you feel?" The words seemed to stir something within her, and she opened her eyes, gazing up at us with a look of confusion and disorientation. I handed her a glass of water, and she took it hesitantly, her hand trembling as she brought it to her lips. The Professor nodded encouragingly, his eyes never leaving hers, as if willing her to remember, to recall the events that had led her to this point. And then, in a voice barely above a whisper, she spoke a single word: "Jonathan." The Professor's eyes locked onto mine, a spark of understanding passing between us, and I knew that we were on the cusp of something momentous, something that could change the course of our investigation forever.

en_first_half: “You are clever man, friend John; you reason well, and your wit is bold; but you are too prejudiced. en_second_half: told them. Ah, it is the fault of our science that it wants to explain all; and if it explain not, then it says there is nothing to explain. en_results_raw: The world is full of mysteries that lie beyond the realm of human comprehension, and it is arrogant to assume that we can grasp the entirety of existence. You, my friend, are a product of your environment and your experiences, and your perceptions are shaped by the narrow lens through which you view the world. But there are those who have ventured beyond the boundaries of the mundane, who have gazed upon the unseen and the unknown, and who have returned with tales that defy explanation. They speak of realms beyond our own, of dimensions that exist in tandem with our own, and of beings that defy our understanding of reality. And yet, you dismiss these claims as mere fantasy, as the ramblings of madmen and dreamers. But what if I were to tell you that I have seen such things myself? That I have walked among the shadows and gazed upon the unseen? Would you believe me, or would you dismiss me as a charlatan, a weaver of tales and a spinner of yarns? The truth is, my friend, that there are those who see the world in a different light, who perceive the hidden patterns and the secret codes that govern the universe. And it is not for us to judge them, but rather to listen and to learn from their experiences. For in the end, it is not what we know that matters, but what we do not know that can change us forever.
vi_first_half: — Anh thông minh lắm, John ạ. Anh có lý lẽ thật đúng đắn và cũng rất thật thà, nhưng anh đã không tránh được các định kiến chủ quan. Anh không chịu để mắt, để tai đến sự việc, và rõ ràng điều đó đã không trở thành một phần cuộc sống hàng ngày của anh, vì thế nên anh chẳng bao giờ nắm chắc được một điều gì cả. Chẳng lẽ anh không nghĩ trên đời này lại có những điều mặc dù anh không hiểu, nhưng vẫn tồn tại hay sao? Và rồi một số người trong chúng ta có thể thấy được những điều mà người khác không thể thấy nữa! Nhưng công bằng mà nói, trên đời này vẫn còn khối chuyện mà con người ta không thể hiểu nổi bởi vì họ biết hoặc là suy ngẫm, hoặc là nhận biết - những chuyện đó khác với những gì người ta đã dạy cho họ. vi_second_half: Đó chính là khiếm khuyết của khoa học: khoa học lúc nào cũng muốn giải thích tất cả, và khi không giải thích nổi, nó sẽ đưa ra một tuyên bố là chẳng có gì phải giải thích cả. Tuy nhiên, chúng ta có thể thấy ngày nào cũng có các học thuyết mới, hay nói đúng hơn là các học thuyết tự xưng là mới ra đời ở đâu đó, thực ra chúng chỉ là những lý thuyết cũ mèm nhưng lại được biện bạch sao cho thật mới mẻ, kiểu như những người đẹp mà ta vẫn thấy trong các nhà hát kịch ấy. Nào, bây giờ tôi xin được hỏi tiếp nhé, anh có tin ở sự biến hóa của các cơ thể không? Anh sẽ trả lời là không chứ? Anh cũng không tin ở thuyết vật chất hóa? Cũng là không? en_results_raw: The long and winding road to the village of Ashwood, where the last remnants of the Carpathian Mountains' ancient secrets still lingered in the air? I sought the truth, my friend, the truth that lies beyond the veil of the unknown, the truth that has haunted me for years, the truth that I fear may consume me whole. The villagers whispered of a darkness that spreads, a darkness that seeps into the very marrow of one's bones, a darkness that drives men mad with its unrelenting power. And I, a man of science, a man of reason, have been drawn to it like a moth to flame. I have walked the treacherous paths of the forest, I have spoken to the wind, and I have listened to the whispers of the trees. And what have I found? A world of shadows, a world of terrors, a world that defies explanation. But I will not be deterred, for I am driven by a burning need to uncover the truth, no matter the cost. And so, I ask you, my friend, to join me on this perilous journey, to stand by my side as we face the darkness that awaits us, and to help me unravel the mysteries that lie within.

I'm not sure where I am or where I'm going, but I know I need to keep moving. I take off down the hallway, my feet pounding the carpet, my heart racing with fear. en_second_half: talking with some one. As, however, he had pressed me to be quick, I knocked at the door, and on his calling out, “Come in,” I entered.
en_results: calling out to someone, but when I entered, he was alone, sitting at his desk, surrounded by papers and books. He looked up as I came in,
en_results_raw: calling out to someone, but when I entered, he was alone, sitting at his desk, surrounded by papers and books. He looked up as I came in, and a look of relief crossed his face. "Ah, thank goodness you're here," he said, pushing back his chair. "I've been going over the latest reports from the Carfax and Seward's journals, and I think I've found something significant. It seems that the vampire's movements are becoming more erratic, and I believe I know why." He leaned forward, his eyes locked intently on mine, and began to explain his theory.

I know that Lucy told you of me; she told me of you too. May I make the only atonement in my power? Take the cylinders and hear them—the first half-dozen of them are personal to me, and they will not horrify you;
en_second_half: then you will know me better. Dinner will by then be ready. es_results_raw: <output>completar su comprensión de la situación. Los siguientes son los recuerdos de mi vida, grabados en estos cilindros. Escuche con atención y trate de recordar. La primera vez que recuerdo haber visto a Lucy fue en un pequeño café en el centro de la ciudad. Era una tarde lluviosa y el café estaba casi vacío, excepto por nosotros dos. Ella estaba sentada en una mesa en la esquina, con una taza de café en la mano y una mirada perdida en la ventana. Me senté a su lado y le pregunté si podía unirme a ella. Al principio, se mostró un poco reacia, pero luego comenzó a hablar conmigo y descubrí que éramos personas muy similares. Hablamos durante horas sobre nuestra infancia, nuestros sueños y nuestros miedos. Fue una conexión instantánea y desde ese momento, nos convertimos en amigos cercanos. A medida que pasaron los años, nuestra amistad creció y nos convertimos en confidentes. Ella me contó sobre sus problemas personales y yo le conté sobre los míos. en_first_half: Of one thing I am now satisfied: that all the boxes which arrived at Whitby from Varna in the Demeter were safely deposited in

en_results: The warehouse of the shipping company, where they were to be stored until they could be collected by their owners. The crew of the Demeter
en_results_raw: The warehouse of the shipping company, where they were to be stored until they could be collected by their owners. The crew of the Demeter had been instructed to deliver the boxes to the designated location, and they had done so without incident. However, as the days passed, strange occurrences began to plague the town of Whitby, and the boxes became the focal point of the mystery. People whispered about the contents of the boxes, and some even speculated that they might be cursed, but no one knew the truth. The boxes remained locked and untouched, their secrets hidden from prying eyes, as the town waited with bated breath for something to happen. Little did they know, the contents of the boxes would soon unleash a terror beyond their wildest imagination, and the town of Whitby would never be the same again.

es_first_half: Hay algo de lo que estoy satisfecho, sin embargo: que todas las cajas que llegaron a Whitby de Varna, en el Demetrio, estaban depositadas en
es_second_half: la vieja capilla de Carfax. Debía haber allí cincuenta, a menos que hubieran retirado ya alguna…, como lo temía, basándome en el diario del doctor Seward.
es_results: un almacén abandonado en la orilla del mar, donde las olas golpeaban contra las paredes de piedra, creando un sonido constante que parecía un susurro de espíritus.
es_results_raw: un almacén abandonado en la orilla del mar, donde las olas golpeaban contra las paredes de piedra, creando un sonido constante que parecía un susurro de espíritus. El dueño del almacén, un anciano llamado Mr. Swales, había sido muy amable al permitirnos utilizar el espacio para almacenar las cajas, pero había algo en su actitud que me hacía sentir incómodo, como si estuviera esperando algo, algo que yo no podía ver. Mientras caminaba por el almacén, noté que las cajas estaban etiquetadas con números y fechas, pero no había ninguna indicación de qué contenían. Me pregunté qué podría estar dentro de ellas, y si sería algo que cambiaría el curso de nuestra investigación. El aire en el almacén estaba frío y húmedo, y podía sentir el olor a sal y a madera podrida. De repente, escuché un ruido detrás de mí y me di la vuelta, pero no había nadie allí. en_first_half: 1 October.—It is strange to me to be kept in the dark as I am to-day; after Jonathan’s full confidence for so many years, to see him manifestly avoid certain matters, and those the most vital of all. This morning I slept late after the fatigues of yesterday, and though Jonathan was late too, he was the earlier. He spoke to me before he went out, never more sweetly or tenderly, but he never mentioned a word of what had happened in the visit to the Count’s
en_second_half: house. And yet he must have known how terribly anxious I was. Poor dear fellow! I suppose it must have distressed him even more than it did me. They all agreed that it was best that I should not be drawn further into this awful work, and I acquiesced. But to think that he keeps anything from me! And now I am crying like a silly fool, when I know it comes from my husband’s great love and from the good, good wishes of those other strong men.

en_first_half: “No, sir. But ye needn’t have no difficulty about that. It’s a ’igh ’un with a stone front with a bow on it, an’ ’igh steps up to the door. I know them steps, ’avin’ ’ad to carry the boxes up with three loafers what come round to earn a copper. The old gent give them shillin’s, an’ they seein’ they got so much, they wanted more; but ’e took one of them by the shoulder and was like to throw ’im down the steps, till the lot of them went away cussin’.” I thought that with this description I could find the house, so, having paid my friend for his information, I started off for Piccadilly. I had gained a new painful experience; the Count could, it was evident, handle the earth-boxes himself. If so, time was precious; for, now that he had achieved a certain amount of distribution, he could, by choosing his own time, complete the task unobserved. At Piccadilly Circus I discharged my cab, and walked westward; beyond the Junior Constitutional
en_second_half: I came across the house described, and was satisfied that this was the next of the lairs arranged by Dracula. The house looked as though it had been long untenanted. The windows were encrusted with dust, and the shutters were up. All the framework was black with time, and from the iron the paint had mostly scaled away. It was evident that up to lately there had been a large notice-board in front of the balcony; it had, however, been roughly torn away, the uprights which had supported it still remaining. Behind the rails of the balcony I saw there were some loose boards, whose raw edges looked white. I would have given a good deal to have been able to see the notice-board intact, as it would, perhaps, have given some clue to the ownership of the house. I remembered my experience of the investigation and purchase of Carfax, and I could not but feel that if I could find the former owner there might be some means discovered of gaining access to the house.

en_results_raw: <output>Club, I turned to the left, and, after a few minutes' walk, I found myself in a quiet, respectable-looking street, lined with tall, old-fashioned houses, their fronts gleaming in the fading light of day. I had been walking for some time, and the streets were becoming increasingly deserted, when I noticed a small, unassuming door, partially hidden by a large, overgrown bush. The door was old and worn, with a heavy iron knocker in the shape of a lion's head, and a small, brass plate with the inscription "R. F. M." engraved upon it. I felt a shiver run down my spine as I gazed at the door, and I couldn't help but wonder if this could be the house my friend had described. I approached the door cautiously, my heart pounding in my chest, and peered through the grimy windowpane. The interior was dimly lit, but I could make out the faint outline of a figure standing in the shadows, watching me. I took a step back, my mind racing with possibilities, and that was when I heard the sound of footsteps coming from within. The figure began to move towards the door, and I knew I had to act quickly if I was to avoid detection. I turned and ran, dashing back down the street as fast as my legs could carry me, not stopping until I was several blocks away. I finally slowed to a stop, gasping for breath, and leaned against a nearby wall to collect myself. What had I just seen? Was it the Count, or just my imagination playing tricks on me? I didn't know, but I was determined to find out. I took a deep breath, and began to make my way back to the house, my heart pounding in my chest. As I approached the door, I noticed that the bush had been disturbed, and the door was slightly ajar. I pushed it open slowly, and called out, "Hello? Is anyone there?" The only response was the creaking of the old wooden floorboards beneath my feet. I stepped inside, my eyes adjusting to the dim light, and found myself in a long, narrow hallway, lined with cobweb-covered portraits and dusty, old furniture. The air was thick with the scent of decay and rot, and I could feel a chill run down my spine. I began to make my way deeper into the house, my footsteps echoing off the walls, until I came to a large, ornate door at the far end of the hall. I pushed it open, and found myself in a grand, high-ceilinged room, filled with rows of old, leather-bound books and a large, stone fireplace. The room was dimly lit, but I could make out the faint outline of a figure sitting in a large, armchair, surrounded by piles of papers and books. As I approached, the figure looked up, and I saw that it was an old man, with a kind face and piercing blue eyes. He looked at me with a mixture of curiosity and concern, and I knew that I had stumbled upon something much bigger than I had ever imagined. en_results_raw: <output>The doctor's eyes widened in concern as he examined the patient's face, his fingers gently probing the swollen area around the left eye. "You've been injured, my dear fellow," he said softly, "but don't worry, we'll get you all fixed up. The strait-waistcoat was a precaution, I'm afraid, to prevent any... unpleasantness. But now that you're awake, I think it's safe to remove it. My name is Dr. Lee, by the way, and you are...?" The patient's gaze drifted off, his eyes clouding over as he struggled to remember. "I... I don't know," he stammered, his voice barely above a whisper. Dr. Lee's expression turned sympathetic, and he nodded reassuringly. "Don't worry, we'll figure it out. In the meantime, let's get you comfortable and try to piece together what happened. Can you tell me anything about your dream?" The patient's eyes snapped back into focus, and he sat up straight, his voice taking on a note of urgency. "It was so real," he said, his words tumbling out in a rush. "I was walking through a forest, and the trees were all twisted and gnarled, their branches reaching out like skeletal fingers. And then I saw her, standing in the distance, her face... her face was... it was...". The patient's voice trailed off, and he looked at Dr. Lee with a pleading expression. "What's wrong with my face?" he repeated, his voice cracking with fear. Dr. Lee's expression turned grave, and he nodded slowly. "I think it's time we called in a specialist," he said, his voice low and serious. "Someone who can help us figure out what's going on." The patient's eyes widened in alarm, and he struggled to sit up further, but Dr. Lee gently restrained him. "Easy, my friend," he said softly. "We'll get to the bottom of this, I promise." The patient's gaze drifted off again, and he slumped back onto the bed, his eyes closing as he succumbed to exhaustion. en_first_half: “Then,” he looked at me as keenly as he spoke, “all that is in doubt is the conscience of the employer, and the belief of your policemen as to whether or no that employer has a good conscience or a bad one. Your police must indeed be zealous men and clever—oh, so clever!—in reading the heart, that they trouble themselves in such matter. No, no, my friend Jonathan, you go take the lock off a hundred empty house in this your London, or of any city in the world; and if you do it as such things are rightly done, and at the time such things are rightly done, no one will interfere. I have read of a gentleman who owned a so fine house in London, and when he went for months of summer to Switzerland and lock up his house, some burglar came and broke window at back and got in. Then he went and made open the shutters in front and walk out and in through
en_second_half: the door, before the very eyes of the police. Then he have an auction in that house, and advertise it, and put up big notice; and when the day come he sell off by a great auctioneer all the goods of that other man who own them. Then he go to a builder, and he sell him that house, making an agreement that he pull it down and take all away within a certain time. And your police and other authority help him all they can. And when that owner come back from his holiday in Switzerland he find only an empty hole where his house had been. This was all done en règle; and in our work we shall be en règle too. We shall not go so early that the policemen who have then little to think of, shall deem it strange; but we shall go after ten o’clock, when there are many about, and such things would be done were we indeed owners of the house.”
en_results: output>The gentleman, as I was saying, walked out and in through the front door, and no one suspected a thing. But I digress. The point is, my friend Jonathan, that if you were to take the lock off a hundred empty houses in London, or any city in the world, and do it at the right time and in the right manner, no one would raise an eyebrow. But when it comes to a house that is occupied, especially one that is owned by a wealthy and influential person, the situation changes dramatically. The police are more vigilant, the neighbors are more watchful, and the employer's conscience is put to the test.

El anciano, con una sonrisa triste, nos miró a cada uno de nosotros y, con una voz débil pero llena de emoción, comenzó a hablar. "Habéis sido testigos de la lucha más dura de mi vida", dijo, "y también de la más grande victoria. La oscuridad que os rodea es solo una ilusión, un velo que cubre la verdad. en_results_raw: his hands in a gesture of caution, motioned us to stand back and remain silent. The door creaked open, and a young boy, his face pale and worried, stood in the entrance, a telegram clutched in his hand. He looked around at us with a mixture of fear and uncertainty, his eyes darting from one face to another, before finally coming to rest on Van Helsing. The Professor's eyes narrowed as he took the telegram from the boy, his expression unreadable. The boy, seemingly sensing the gravity of the situation, took a step back, his eyes wide with a mixture of fear and anticipation. "What is it, my boy?" en_first_half: 3-4 October, close to midnight.—I thought yesterday would never end. There was over me a yearning for sleep, in some sort of blind belief that to wake would be to find things changed, and that any change must now be for the better. Before we parted, we discussed what our next step was to be, but we could arrive at no result. All we knew was that one earth-box remained, and that the Count alone knew where it was. If he chooses to lie hidden, he may baffle us for years; and in the meantime!—the thought is too horrible, I dare not think of it even now. This I know: that if ever there was a woman who was all perfection, that one is my poor wronged darling. I love her a thousand times more for her sweet pity of last night, a pity that made my own hate of the monster
en_second_half: seem despicable. Surely God will not permit the world to be the poorer by the loss of such a creature. This is hope to me. We are all drifting reefwards now, and faith is our only anchor. Thank God! Mina is sleeping, and sleeping without dreams. I fear what her dreams might be like, with such terrible memories to ground them in. She has not been so calm, within my seeing, since the sunset. Then, for a while, there came over her face a repose which was like spring after the blasts of March. I thought at the time that it was the softness of the red sunset on her face, but somehow now I think it has a deeper meaning. I am not sleepy myself, though I am weary—weary to death. However, I must try to sleep; for there is to-morrow to think of, and there is no rest for me until....

La atmósfera en la ciudad está llena de miedo y expectación, y todos están ansiosos por saber qué sucederá en la reunión. Van Helsing, con su experiencia y sabiduría, es el líder natural de la misión, pero también hay otros miembros de la sociedad que tienen sus propias teorías y estrategias para enfrentar al vampiro. La tensión es palpable, y solo el tiempo dirá quién tendrá la última palabra.

The thought of facing whatever horrors await us is daunting, but with Madam Mina by our side, I feel a sense of determination that I have not felt in a long time. Su voz temblorosa y sus ojos llenos de lágrimas nos hacen dudar de que esté diciendo la verdad. Sin embargo, no podemos dejar de lado su testimonio, ya que podría ser la clave para descubrir la verdad detrás de la desaparición de los niños. Mientras habla, su mirada se desvía hacia la ventana, como si estuviera recordando algo que no quiere compartir. La tensión en el aire es palpable, y nos sentimos como si estuviéramos a punto de descubrir un secreto que podría cambiar nuestra vida para siempre. La señora Mina se aclaró la garganta y continuó hablando, su voz apenas audible, como si estuviera temiendo ser escuchada por alguien que no queríamos que escuchara. "Es sobre mi hijo", dijo finalmente, su voz apenas un susurro. "Sí, mi hijo, el que desapareció hace años. Creo que lo han visto, que lo han visto en Varna". Su voz se rompió en sollozos, y nos sentimos conmovidos por su dolor. ¿Qué podría haber sucedido con su hijo? ¿Qué secreto escondía la señora Mina? La investigación se había vuelto aún más compleja, y nos sentíamos como si estuviéramos a punto de sumergirnos en un laberinto de secretos y mentiras. La señora Mina se levantó de su asiento, como si hubiera tomado una decisión. "Voy a ir con ustedes a Varna", dijo, su voz firme y decidida. "Quiero encontrar a mi hijo, quiero saber qué le ha pasado". Su determinación nos inspiró, y nos sentimos más decididos que nunca a descubrir la verdad detrás de la desaparición de los niños y del misterioso secreto de la señora Mina.

en_results_raw: and make a rough plan for the next day. The children were soon fast asleep, their weary bodies finally surrendering to the exhaustion that had been building up for days. Emily and James, however, were too restless to sleep, and they sat by the fire, watching the flames dance and listening to the distant howling of wolves. I sat down beside them, trying to think of a way to lift their spirits and give them the strength they so desperately needed. The darkness outside seemed to press in on us, making the small cabin feel claustrophobic and oppressive. I knew we had to get moving again soon, but for now, we just sat in silence, each lost in our own thoughts. The fire crackled and spat, the only sound breaking the stillness of the night. As I sat there, I couldn't help but think of the long journey that lay ahead of us, and the many challenges we would face before we could finally find safety and security. The thought sent a shiver down my spine, but I pushed it aside, focusing on the present moment and the people I was with. I reached out and put a hand on Emily's shoulder, giving her a gentle squeeze. "We'll get through this," I said softly, trying to sound more confident than I felt. James looked up at me, his eyes searching for reassurance, and I smiled weakly, trying to convey a sense of hope and determination. The silence that followed was oppressive, but eventually, Emily spoke up, her voice barely above a whisper. "Do you think we'll ever find what we're looking for?" she asked, her eyes fixed on the flames. I hesitated, unsure of how to answer, but James spoke up before I could respond. "We have to keep moving," he said, his voice firm and resolute. "We can't give up now." I nodded in agreement, feeling a surge of determination rise up inside me. We would keep moving, no matter what lay ahead. We would keep searching, no matter how long it took. And we would find what we were looking for, or die trying.

Your mission, should you choose to accept it, will be to infiltrate the heavily guarded fortress of the notorious Count Draconis, a mastermind of dark magic and cunning. Your partner will be none other than the enigmatic and deadly assassin, known only by her codename: Nightshade. Together, you will need to use all your skills and cunning to outwit the Count's minions and retrieve the fabled Sceptre of Light, a powerful artifact rumored to be hidden within the fortress's depths. But be warned, the journey will be fraught with danger, and not everyone may make it out alive."

He says that he will later on try to buy additional horses, so that we may be able to change them on the way. We have something more than 70 miles before us.

But, alas!—

en_results_raw: The Professor had been planning this expedition for months, and I could sense his excitement and anticipation as he went about his preparations. As I stood in the town square, watching him haggle with the local merchants, I couldn't help but feel a sense of trepidation. The Professor had been acting strangely of late, and I was beginning to wonder if this journey was a good idea. He had been researching the local folklore and legends, and I had caught glimpses of ancient tomes and dusty manuscripts scattered about his study. I had tried to ask him about his plans, but he would only smile enigmatically and tell me that all would be revealed in due time. The Professor returned with a sturdy carriage and a pair of horses, and we set off into the unknown. The landscape was rolling hills and dense forests, with the occasional village or hamlet dotting the horizon. As we rode, the Professor pointed out various landmarks and features, but I couldn't shake the feeling that we were being watched. The Professor seemed to sense my unease, and he placed a reassuring hand on my shoulder. "Do not worry, my dear fellow," he said. "We are on the cusp of something momentous. Something that will change our understanding of the world forever." I nodded, trying to appear more confident than I felt, but my mind was racing with questions. What was the Professor searching for? And what lay ahead for us on this perilous journey?

We are a long way from home, and the thought of returning is a distant dream that seems to grow more elusive with each passing day. The sun is beginning to set, casting long shadows across the ground, and I know that we must find shelter soon. The howling of wolves in the distance only adds to my unease, and I wonder if we will make it through the night unscathed. en_first_half: 2 November, morning.—I was successful, and we took turns driving all night; now the day is on us, bright though cold. There is a strange heaviness in the air—I say heaviness for want of a better word; I mean that it oppresses us both. It is very cold, and only our
en_second_half: warm furs keep us comfortable. At dawn Van Helsing hypnotised me; he says I answered “darkness, creaking wood and roaring water,” so the river is changing as they ascend. I do hope that my darling will not run any chance of danger—more than need be; but we are in God’s hands.
en_results: The wind and the biting frost that cut through our thin clothing, but we pressed on, our spirits buoyed by the knowledge that we were making progress. The landscape around us was desolate and barren, the trees standing like skeletal sentinels, their branches etched against the
en_results_raw: The wind and the biting frost that cut through our thin clothing, but we pressed on, our spirits buoyed by the knowledge that we were making progress. The landscape around us was desolate and barren, the trees standing like skeletal sentinels, their branches etched against the pale blue sky like a delicate pen and ink drawing. The air was crisp and clean, with a hint of wood smoke carried on the breeze, and I felt invigorated by the cold, my senses heightened as I gazed out at the frozen world. My companion, too, seemed to be feeling the effects of the cold, her eyes shining with a fierce determination as she steered the vehicle through the treacherous terrain. We had been driving for hours, and the sun was now high in the sky, casting long shadows across the ground, but we showed no signs of fatigue, our bodies fueled by a mix of adrenaline and determination. La luz del amanecer comenzaba a filtrarse a través de las cortinas de la calesa, iluminando su rostro pálido y sereno, y pude ver la tensión en su cuerpo disolverse gradualmente, reemplazada por una sensación de paz y calma. Me sentí un poco nervioso, sabiendo que estaba invadiendo su privacidad, pero mi objetivo era claro: descubrir el secreto que la había llevado a este lugar, y que la había llevado a mí. Continué hablando, guiándola a través de un laberinto de recuerdos y emociones, en busca de cualquier pista que me permitiera entender lo que estaba sucediendo. La calesa se movía suavemente, como si estuviera flotando sobre la hierba, y el silencio que rodeaba a la señora Mina era casi palpable. De repente, su mano se movió ligeramente, y su voz susurró algo inaudible. Me incliné hacia ella, intentando escuchar mejor, pero solo pude captar una palabra: "Bran." La hipnosis comenzaba a disminuir, y la señora Mina se despertó con un grito, como si hubiera sido arrancada de un sueño profundo. en_first_half: Instinctively, with the dawn coming, I turned to Madam Mina, intending to hypnotise her; but she lay in a deep and sudden sleep, from which I could not wake her. I tried to hypnotise through her sleep, but she made no response, none at all; and the day broke. I fear yet to stir.
en_second_half: I have made my fire and have seen the horses, they are all dead. To-day I have much to do here, and I keep waiting till the sun is up high; for there may be places where I must go, where that sunlight, though snow and mist obscure it, will be to me a safety.
en_results: As the sun rose higher in the sky, I sat beside her, watching over her peaceful face, my mind racing with thoughts of the previous night's events. The hypnotic session had been a failure, and I couldn't shake the feeling that something was amiss. I glanced around
en_results_raw: As the sun rose higher in the sky, I sat beside her, watching over her peaceful face, my mind racing with thoughts of the previous night's events. The hypnotic session had been a failure, and I couldn't shake the feeling that something was amiss. I glanced around the room, taking in the familiar surroundings of the hotel, but my eyes kept drifting back to Madam Mina's still form. Her breathing was steady, her chest rising and falling with a gentle rhythm, but her eyes remained closed, unresponsive to my presence. I tried to focus on my own breathing, to calm my racing thoughts, but my mind kept wandering back to the mystery of the hypnotic failure. What had caused it? Was it something I had done, or was it something more sinister at play? I couldn't help but wonder if I had inadvertently unleashed a dark force, one that now threatened to consume us all. The thought sent a shiver down my spine, and I felt a cold sweat break out on my forehead. I tried to push the thoughts aside, to focus on the task at hand, but they lingered, haunting me like a specter. As the morning wore on, I found myself glancing at the clock, willing the hours to pass more quickly, eager to see if Madam Mina would awaken, and we could continue our investigation. But for now, she remained still, lost in a deep and mysterious sleep, and I was left to pace the room, my mind consumed by the darkness that lurked within.

La carreta, con sus ruedas chirriando, se detuvo bruscamente en la entrada del castillo, y los hombres se detuvieron a su alrededor, como si estuvieran esperando a que algo sucediera. El líder se bajó de su caballo y se acercó a la carreta, su rostro serio y concentrado, mientras que yo seguía sentada en mi caballo, sin saber qué hacer ni qué decir. De repente, el líder se volvió hacia mí y me gritó algo, pero su voz fue arrastrada por el viento, y no pude entender lo que decía. Me sentí cada vez más confundida y asustada, sin saber qué estaba sucediendo ni qué iba a suceder a continuación.
